title: Barnard Mountain
listingDescription: Discover the spectacular views of Mount Katahdin and Katahdin Lake from Barnard Mountain.

images.altText: An overlook of an expansive forest with a lake and mountain range in the background
images.title: Barnard Mountain
images.caption: Spectacular views of the Katahdin landscape from Barnard Mountain

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
A 2 mile out and back trail leads to the top of 1,558ft (474 m) Barnard Mountain. Barnard Mountain offers an exceptional view of Mount Katahdin, Katahdin Lake, and the valley below. The hike begins on an old logging road (also known as a tote road) and passes through deciduous forest at the lower elevations. As you gain elevation, you will pass through stunning boreal forest and glacial erratics.

Biking is not permitted on the trail up to Barnard Mountain.
 

Elevation Gain: 792ft / 241m

Distance (Round-Trip): 4 miles

Difficulty: Easy to Moderate

Restrooms: There are no restrooms available at the trailhead. The closest vault toilet is at the Katahdin Overlook also on the Loop Road. There is another vault toilet at Deasey Ponds Parking Area.

Water: Potable water is not available at this location.

Parking: The most direct access point to Barnard Mountain is at the trailhead located near mile 12 of the Katahdin Loop Road (45.91561,-68.76049).

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: A steep granite ledge with views of Mount Katahdin, Katahdin Lake, and the valley below. To the left of Mount Katahdin the forests continue into the horizon. Surrounding the rocky ledge are thick towering spruce trees with undergrowth below. There is a picnic table on the ledge.

title: Barnard Mountain Trailhead
listingDescription: Whether you're starting a grand adventure on the International Appalachian Trail or you're going for a day hike up Barnard Mountain, this is where your journey will begin.

images.altText: Dirt logging road surrounded by forest with a wooden trailhead sign.
images.title: International Appalachian Trail Terminus
images.caption: Wooden IAT and Barnard Mountain Trailhead sign next to a dirt road.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText:
The Barnard Mountain trailhead is located just before mile marker 12 on the Katahdin Loop Road. The hike to the top of Barnard Mountain is 4 miles round trip. From the top there is a spectacular view of neighboring Baxter State Park and Mount Katahdin. 

The International Appalachian Trail (IAT) also starts from this trailhead. The IAT extends on from the Appalachian Trail. The trail follows the ancient Appalachian Mountains, now separated by the North Atlantic Ocean. The IAT links traces of these mountains around the arc of the North Atlantic. The section of the trail that runs through Maine starts here and continues through the national monument for 30 miles, then continues another 100 miles to Fort Fairfield, Maine, and then on into Canada, Greenland, and Europe, ending in Morocco.
audioDescription: A rugged dirt road goes off into a both mountainous and forested landscape to the north. Right in front there is a wooden sign for the trailhead of Barnard Mountain and the Southern Terminus of the International Appalachian Trail. T the loop road continues into the forest in the south and east. A wall of thick deciduous forest covers the view to the west.

title: Bowlin Falls
listingDescription: The majestic views of Bowlin Falls awaits when paddling the East Branch of the Penobscot River.

images.altText: Rapids and a small waterfall along a turbulent section of river surrounded by forest on both sides.
images.title: Bowlin Falls
images.caption: Bowlin Falls along the East Branch of the Penobscot River.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText: While paddling down the East Branch of the Penobscot River, Bowlin Falls is the last waterfall and portage within national monument boundaries, There are no trails to Bowlin Falls and it is only accessible by water.
audioDescription: A small waterfall along a turbulent section of river with rocky ledges and forests on both sides of the river.

title: Deasey Mountain
listingDescription: The summit of Deasey Mountain offers incredible views of Mount Katahdin and the forested region around it.

images.altText: Tall pine trees frame a view of a green, peaked mountain in the distance
images.title: View of Mt Katahdin from Deasey Mountain
images.caption: Deasey Mountain provides spectacular view of Mount Katahdin

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
At 1,942 feet, Deasey Mountain is the tallest peak in Katahdin Woods and Waters. The summit offers 360-degree views of the surrounding landscape. Access to Deasey Mountain is by way of the International Appalachian Trail, with the shortest hiking distance being five miles from Wassataquoik Gate. A ford across Wassataquoik Stream is necessary.

Sitting atop the mountain is the historic Deasey Mountain fire lookout. The lookout was constructed by the Maine Forest Service in 1929 and used for fire detection until 1969. It is one of the very few ground houses in Maine. Camping is not permitted at the peak or at the fire lookout. Please reserve a campsite or continue to hike to a designated site within the monument.
 

Elevation Gain: 1,593ft / 485m

Distance (Round-Trip): 10 miles

Difficulty: Difficult

Restrooms: A vault toilet is located in the parking area at the Wassataquoik Gate trailhead.

Parking: Parking is available at Wassataquoik gate trailhead on Orin Falls Road.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

Use caution when fording Wassataquoik Stream. Review stream crossing safety before your trip. There is no potable water within the monument. Plan accordingly!
audioDescription: The summit of Deasey Mountain has a clearing for a 360-degree viewpoint. The summit is surrounded with shrubs and trees. A thick forested landscape stretches into the distance. There is a historic fire lookout building at the top of the mountain.

title: Deasey Mountain Fire Lookout
listingDescription: Explore the history of wildfire prevention and get spectacular views from this lookout on a backountry mountain peak.

images.altText: One room fire lookout surrounded by subalpine vegetation and spruce.
images.title: Deasey Mountain Fire Lookout
images.caption: The historic Deasey Mountain Fire Lookout.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText: One of the very few groundhouse lookouts in Maine, Deasey Mountain Lookout was constructed by the Maine Forest Service in 1929 and used for detection until 1969.
audioDescription: Wooden one room structure with windows and support cables on each corner of the structure. Surrounded by subalpine vegetation and spruce trees with beautiful views to the west and south of the mountainous and forested Katahdin landscape.

title: Deasey Ponds
listingDescription: Enjoy the view and sounds of the forest at a quiet scenic pond. Deasey Ponds offers opportunities to observe the flora and fauna of a wetland habitat.

images.altText: A wooden viewing platform with a bench over a grassy pond. Cloudy blue sky and mountains behind it.
images.title: Deck with Benches at Deasey Pond
images.caption: The calm tranquil view at Deasey Ponds.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Deasey Pond is one of the shorter hikes available within Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument at 0.6 miles one-way. This hike offers a charming view of a pond within the northern boreal forests of Maine. With glacial erratics breaking the water’s surface you can see clues of the landscape’s glacial past. The pond’s trailhead is located just before mile 1 on the Katahdin Loop Road.
 

Elevation Gain: 72ft / 21m

Distance(Round-Trip): 1.2 miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: There is a vault toilet at the parking area.

Parking: Parking is available just west of the trailhead. The parking area is located to the right on the Loop Road at approximately 45.87072,-68.68235

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: A wooden viewing platform sits on the edge of a pond. The platform, made of wide wooden planks, has railings about 4 feet tall. There are benches built into either side for visitors to sit on both the left and right side of the platform. The pond appears to be relatively shallow, due to the abundance of grass growing around and in the pond. There are several grass patches growing in the still water. Large granite boulders are visible, which were deposited by glaciers long ago. The pond is surrounded by boreal forest, composed largely of tall pine trees. Small, rolling tree-covered mountains fill out the background of the scene.

title: Deasey Ponds Trail Parking Lot
listingDescription: Park here to access the Deasey Ponds Trail.

images.altText: A one-way dirt parking area with a vault toilet to the left of the entrance.
images.title: Deasey Ponds Trail Parking Lot
images.caption: The entrance to Deasey Ponds Trail Parking Lot.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText:
Park your vehicle here to begin your scenic hike to Deasey Ponds and/or carefully cross the road south of the parking lot and follow an esker south to a beautiful viewpoint. This is a one way traffic parking lot and fits approximately 10 vehicles. Please follow the enter and exit signs accordingly. There is a vault toilet located to the left by the entrace. There is no potable water. 

Accessibility:
The surface of the parking area is made of dirt, gravel, and rocks. It is leveled, but the surface can be uneven and muddy depending on the season. The vault toilet meets ADA standards.

Hours:
Open 24/7 when the Katahdin Loop Road is opened to traffic.

Getting Here:
Take Swift Brook Road to reach the parking area at approximately 45.87072,-68.68235
audioDescription: A one-way dirt and gravel parking lot that fits approximately 10 vehicles. A brown vault toilet is located by the entrance on the left.

title: Esker Wetland
listingDescription: A beautiful short hike to a scenic river landscape area.

images.altText: A small bench made of logs sit next to tall green shrubs nearby a wetland.
images.title: Bench at Sandbank Stream Deadwater
images.caption: A small bench provides seating for wildlife viewers at the Esker Wetland.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Esker Wetland offers a viewpoint of a wetland ecosystem formed by Sandbank Stream. This calm wetland area is bordered by deciduous forest.

Start at the Deasey Ponds Trail parking lot to access Esker Wetland. Follow a trail atop an esker and down to the wetland viewpoint. Use caution to cross the road south of the parking lot to find the trailhead that leads to the viewpoint. Depending on conditions, this area may experience flooding and high water levels.


Elevation Gain: 50ft / 15m

Distance (Round-Trip): 1 mile

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: A vault toilet is located at at Deasey Ponds Trailhead parking lot.

Parking: Park at the Deasey Ponds parking lot.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: The Sandbank Stream Deadwater is a beautiful marshy habitat with deciduous forest all along the edge of the marshy grass habitat. This is a fantastic place to hear the sounds of nature and potentially wildlife like various species of birds.

title: Grand Pitch
listingDescription: Come see the crown jewel of the East Branch of the Penobscot River.

images.altText: White water drops down a waterfall flowing through the forest
images.title: Grand Pitch
images.caption: A wild and spectacular section of the East Branch of the Penobscot River.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText:
Grand Pitch spans approximately 200 feet across the East Branch of the Penobscot River and drops approximately 20 feet. The river at Grand Pitch cuts through some of the oldest rocks in the local area. The Grand Pitch Formation is predominately slate (metamorphic rock), siltsone (sedimentary rock), and fine-grained quartzite (metamorphic rock). The rocks of the Grand Pitch formation are believed to date to the early Cambrian period, over approximately 500 million years ago. Hike or bike along the IAT to experience this geological feature. Paddlers must portage around Grand Pitch.
 

Elevation Gain: 166ft / 50m

Distance (Round-Trip): 7 miles

Difficulty: Moderate

Restrooms: Vault toilets are available at the North Gate parking lot and Oxbow Picnic Area.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate trailhead parking area.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: A steep forested ledge overlooking a 20 feet high and 200 feet wide waterfall below. The spruce trees block some of the views of the waterfall. The river flows from left to right as it goes around the riverbend that curves to the left. Rocks and dips in the river cause white-water through spots in the river. Trees line both sides of the river and falls.

title: Haskell Gate
listingDescription: Vehicle access on New River Road ends here. Visitors wishing to access points of interest or hike-in campsites in the northern section of the monument can park their vehicles here. Note: During winter months, vehicles must park at the North Gate parking area and travel by foot to Haskell Gate.

images.altText: A gravel and dirt trail at Haskell Gate that leads into the woods.
images.title: Haskell Gate
images.caption: A multi-use trail provides access to many areas in the northern section.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText:
Haskell Gate is where visitors can access points of interest or hike-in campsites in the northern section of the monument. All trails past Haskell Gate are for hiking or biking only. Just south of the gate on New River Road is a designated parking area for vehicles. Please do not park in front of the gate or block the gate.

Note: During the winter, New River Road is closed at the North Gate. Vehicles must park at the North Gate parking area. Visitors can access Haskell Gate by foot. Ski trails are often groomed to Haskell Gate from January through March.
audioDescription: Vehicle access on New River Road ends here. Visitors wishing to access points of interest or hike-in campsites in the northern section of the monument along the East Branch of the Penobscot River can park their vehicles at the parking area just south of the gate. Note: During winter months, vehicles cannot travel past the North Gate. However, ski trails are often groomed to Haskell Gate from January through March.

title: Haskell Rock Pitch
listingDescription: Haskell Rock is a 20-foot pillar in the East Branch Penobscot River located in the midst of Haskell Rock Pitch.

images.altText: A rounded stone pillar approximately 20 feet protrudes from the East Branch Penobscot River.
images.title: Haskell Rock Pitch
images.caption: Haskell Rock arises from the East Branch Penobscot River.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText:
Haskell Rock Pitch refers to the series of rapids in the East Branch of the Penobscot River.  A large 20-foot high conglomerate rock (a coarse-grained sedimentary rock composed of fragments larger than 2 millimeters in diameter), Haskell Rock protrudes out from the rapids. The conglomerate rock feature is named after a logger, William Haskell, who died here.

Paddlers are advised to take portage trails around all rapids within the monument. For those traveling by foot or bicycle, start at Haskell Gate and follow the trail east for approximately 2 miles. A primitive campsite is located at nearby at Haskell Deadwater.
 

Elevation Gain: 103ft / 31m

Distance (Round-Trip): 4 Miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: The closest vault toilets are located at the North Gate parking lot and at Oxbow Picnic Area.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: A tall, rounded and bulging pillar of conglomerate rock (a coarse-grained sedimentary rock composed of fragments larger than 2 millimeters in diameter) stands approximately 20 feet high in the middle of the East Branch Penobscot River. The large rock is close to the bank of the river, next to a large rapid. The forest lines both sides of the river.

title: Katahdin Overlook
listingDescription: Picnic area and scenic viewpoint on the Katahdin Loop Road. Excellent views of Katahdin and the surrounding landscape, and a popular astronomy site after sunset.

images.altText: A green mountain peak rises above the treetops. In the foreground are boulders and grass.
images.title: The Overlook
images.caption: The Overlook is one of the best places to view Mount Katahdin within the monument.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: Travelers on the Katahdin Loop Road can pause here to enjoy unparalleled views of Katahdin, Millinocket Lake, and other prominent landmarks stretching out to the west. Access is via a short driveway at Mile 6.4 leading uphill to a clearing and parking area. A vault toilet and several picnic tables make this a popular rest stop. After sunset, this location also serves as an excellent night-sky viewing area for stargazers. Camping is located nearby at the Sandbank Stream campsites.
audioDescription: A short dirt driveway turns off the Katahdin Loop Road and travels uphill to a clearing. Picnic tables are positioned next to a parking area, and a vault toilet is found near the rear of the clearing. Treetops on the western slope of the hillside have been trimmed to open up a viewshed of Katahdin. In the distance, Mount Katahdin rises from an expanse of forest. The mountain has a sharp, triangular peak in the middle of two flat tables.

title: Katahdin Viewpoint
listingDescription: Great views of Katahdin from afar awaits at this viewpoint.

images.altText: A parking lot and viewpoint surrounded by trees with Katahdin in the distance on the horizon,
images.title: Katahdin Viewpoint
images.caption: A great landscape view of Katahdin.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText: Katahdin Viewpoint is a remote location in the Seboeis Parcel to enjoy a glimpse of Mount Katahdin from a the distance. It is also a good location to stargaze at night. There are no facilities at this location.
audioDescription: A gravel and dirt parking lot with a glimpse of Mount Katahdin and Traveler Mountain just above the treetops to the west with forests surrounding the parking area.

title: Kimball Deadwater
listingDescription: Kimball Deadwater is a wetland area located just off of American Thread Road in the Seboeis Parcel. The habitat here provides a chance to view a variety of wildlife.

images.altText: A view of large wetland surrounded by trees. The still water reflects a cloudy blue sky.
images.title: Kimball Deadwater
images.caption: View of the landscape at Kimball Deadwater.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Kimball Deadwater is a wetland area located next to the American Thread Road. It is an important habitat for a variety of wildlife, making it a great viewing area for wildlife. You may see waterfowl, amphibians, beavers, or even moose while visiting Kimball Deadwater.

Elevation Gain: None

Distance (Round-Trip): 0.2 miles

Restrooms: There are no restrooms available in this section of the monument.

Parking: Parking is available at the trailhead located on the American Thread Road.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: A wetland area surrounded by dense forest. The water is shallow and still. Vegetation grows in the water.

title: Little Messer Pond
listingDescription: Little Messer Pond is a tranquil place for solitude deep within Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.

images.altText: A pond reflects a clear sky as the sunsets behind the forest and distant mountains
images.title: Little Messer Pond at sunset
images.caption: The calm and tranquil sunset at Little Messer Pond

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Little Messer Pond is one of the few tranquil ponds deep within Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument. The pond features unique plant life including peat moss and pitcher plants. It also offers great views of the Traveler Mountain. The shortest route to Little Messer Pond is along the International Appalachian Trail beginning at Haskell Gate.
 

Elevation Gain: 116ft / 35m

Distance (Round-Trip): 6 miles

Difficulty: Easy to moderate

Restrooms: Vault toilets are available at the North Gate and Oxbow Picnic Area. Follow best practices for remote waste management if needed.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate parking area.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: A calm pond surrounded by thick vegetation and forests. In the distance mountains rise to the west.

title: Lunksoos Boat Launch
listingDescription: Access the East Branch of the Penobscot River by canoe or kayak here, or fish along the bank.

images.altText: A gravel horse-shoe shaped driveway provides access for boats to the river
images.title: Lunksoos Boat Launch
images.caption: The Lunksoos area has picnicing, paddling, and camping all in one spot

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
At the heart of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument lies the East Branch of the Penobscot River, which runs the length of the monument north to south. From native Penobscots to noted American visitors like Henry David Thoreau, this waterway has been an important corridor of travel for centuries.

Lunksoos Boat Launch is a small gravel boat launch near the historic site of Lunksoos Camps. It offers a put-in point for paddlers wishing to head upstream to the river's confluence with the Seboeis, or downstream to Whetstone Falls and the main stem of the Penobscot beyond.

The parking lot and vault toilet is located across the Seboeis Road. Unload your belongings by the boat ramp and park in the designated parking lot.
audioDescription: A dirt road loops down to the eastern bank of the East Branch of the Penobscot River, where a small boat launch is located. A small parking area lies at the bottom of the loop and a picnic table is found nearby. A vault toilet is located a short distance uphill from the boat launch.

title: Lunksoos Mountain
listingDescription: Lunksoos Mountain is one of the most remote, wild, and breathtaking mountain peak views at Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.

images.altText: A mountain top lookout with many rolling green mountains in the distance
images.title: Lunksoos Mountain
images.caption: The views in all directions from this wild peak are nothing short of breathtaking.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Lunksoos Mountain at 1,762 ft / 537 m, is within the heart of Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument. From the peak you will see magnificent views of forests, rivers, and mountains all around, including Mount Katahdin. Reach the top of Lunksoos Mountain by hiking 6.3 miles one-way along the International Appalachian Trail from Wassataquoik Gate trailhead. A stream crossing is necessary by Wassataquoik Ford to reach the summit.
 

Elevation Gain: 1,332ft / 405m

Distance (Round-Trip): 12.6 miles

Difficulty: Difficult

Restrooms: A vault toilet is located in the parking area at the Wassataquoik Gate trailhead.

Parking: Parking is available at Wassataquoik Gate.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

Use caution when fording Wassataquoik Stream. Review stream crossing safety before your trip.
audioDescription: Granite rocky peak with black spruce growing all around. A mountain range that includes Katahdin and Traveler rise to the west. Deasey Mountain rises close by to the south. To the east is Mount Chase off in the distant and the large and wild East Branch of the Penobscot River meandering through a valley down below. In all directions endless forest, ponds, and lakes the go to the horizon. No signs of human presence, except for the trail below your feet and the sign marking Lunksoos Mountain.

title: Lynx Pond
listingDescription: Wildlife viewing and/or a relaxing reprieve await visitors at scenic Lynx Pond.

images.altText: A wooden platform extends out into a grassy wetland surrounded by trees
images.title: The viewing platform on Lynx Pond
images.caption: Lynx Pond is along an ADA accessible trail off of Katahdin Loop Road

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Lynx Pond is accessed via a short out and back, ADA accessible trail. The viewing platform at Lynx Pond offers those driving along the Katahdin Loop Road a chance to get out of their vehicle and observe a rich natural community within the monument. Standing in the open air you may hear the rapping of a woodpecker’s beak against bark, the splashing of a duck’s wing against water, or see a solitary moose diving below the surface to snack on aquatic vegetation. Look for signs to Lynx Pond at mile 2.2 of the Katahdin Loop Road.

Elevation Gain: None

Distance (Round-Trip): 0.2 miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: There are no restrooms available at the trailhead. The closest vault toilet is at Deasey Ponds Parking Area.

Water: Potable water is not available at this location.

Parking: There is ADA parking next to the trailhead. More parking is available just past the trailhead on the Katahdin Loop Road. Once parked, follow the short gravel trail from the parking area that will lead you back to the Lynx Pond Trailhead.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: A short gravel trail through the woods ends at a wooden viewing platform which extends into the shore of a pond. The still, reflective water is surrounded by an expanse of grass and tall trees.

title: Messer Pond
listingDescription: Messer Pond is a Great Pond and a heritage pond located at a remote and densely forested area of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.

images.altText: A large still pond reflects surrounding trees and cloudy skies.
images.title: View of Messer Pond
images.caption: Messer Pond is both a Great Pond and a heritage pond.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Messer Pond is one of five state heritage ponds in Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument. It is also one of four Great Ponds within the monument. The state of Maine gives heritage fish waters special protection because wild brook trout are self-sustaining and not maintained by stocking. Messer Pond was last stocked in 1961. Invasive fish pose a major threat to these wild brook trout.

Messer Pond is located in a remote area of the monument and requires a 9 mile out and back hike.
 

Elevation: 179ft / 54m

Distance: 9 miles

Difficulty: Moderate

Restrooms: The nearest vault toilets are located at the North Gate parking lot and Oxbow Picnic Area.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate parking lot.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: A 27-acre remote pond surrounded by dense shrubbery and forest. The pond is longer than it is wide. It is a heritage pond containing wild brook trout.

title: Mile 0 Katahdin Loop Road Entrance
listingDescription: The entrance to the Katahdin Loop Road, a 17-mile scenic drive with views of nearby Mount Katahdin and opportunities for hiking and wildlife viewing.

images.altText: A dirt road leading into the woods: an open metal gate and park welcome sign on either side
images.title: The gate at Mile 0 of the Loop Road
images.caption: Welcome to the south section of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: Welcome to the Katahdin Loop Road, a 17-mile scenic drive through Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument. Scenic views and wildlife viewing opportunities abound past the gate at Mile 0, and various trails for hiking, bicycling, or horseback riding can be accessed along this route. A small pullout before the entrance to the offers parking for a single vehicle and access to a nearby marsh via a short trail up and over a prominent glacial esker.
audioDescription: An open gate next to a wooden sign with the words "Welcome to Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument. Overnight parking within by permit only. No hunting." Attached are icons indicate vehicle access, leashed pets, horseback riding, bicycling, and picnicking are permitted. A separate sign reading "Mile 0" is located across the dirt road, which continues past the gate along a tree-lined route.

title: Mile 1 Katahdin Loop Road-First View
listingDescription: The first of many scenic views of Mount Katahdin awaits those who travel the Katahdin Loop Road.

images.altText: A distant mountain rises above the horizon of dense forest
images.title: First View
images.caption: A distant view of Mount Katahdin entices those on the Katahdin Loop Road to continue their journey.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: Just past mile marker 1 on the Katahdin Loop Road, a small pullout on the left provides a first view of almost mile-high Mount Katahdin at 5,267 feet above sea level in neighboring Baxter State Park. Katahdin, which translates to “greatest mountain” in Penobscot, is adjacent to the monument and the prominent visual feature in the region. Katahdin is held sacred by the Maliseet, Micmac, Passamaquoddy, and Penobscot nations and the geology within and around the monument is central to oral histories, traditions, and cultural practices for each tribal community.
audioDescription: The mountain called Katahdin towers over distant treetops as viewed from a small unpaved vehicle pullout along the roadside. A sign reads "First View" above an illustration of binoculars.

title: Mile 3.2 Katahdin Loop Road-Black Spruce Bog
listingDescription: The Black Spruce Bog is a unique ecosystem in Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument and a birder's paradise.

images.altText: Thin mangy black spruce growing out of a bog.
images.title: Black Spruce Bog
images.caption: Black Spruce Bog along the Katahdin Loop Road.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText: Along the roadside a black spruce bog contains rhodora (wild azalea) and swamp maple as well as a variety of other ferns and bog plants. Listen and watch for alder flycatcher, magnolia, palm and Canada warblers, swamp and white-throated sparrows, and hermit thrush.
audioDescription: A rugged dirt logging road cuts through a black spruce bog with withered black spruce and thick spongy wet undergrowth.

title: Mile 7.7 Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint
listingDescription: Breathtaking views of the Katahdin landscape await from this location along the Katahdin Loop Road.

images.altText: Deciduous forest valley in front with Katahdin towering above in the background.
images.title: Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint - Mile 7.7
images.caption: Marvel at the wonders of the Katahdin landscape.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText: Mile 7.7 on the Katahdin Loop Road offers a great view of Katahdin as well as the surrounding forests.
audioDescription: On a rugged dirt logging road with a viewshed of a valley and Katahdin to the left. The forest is a mixture of deciduous and boreal with spruce, maples, pines, oaks, and many more all blended together throughout the landscape.

title: Mile 8 Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint
listingDescription: Peer through the forest's clearing at Katahdin.

images.altText: A view of Mount Katahdin is framed by trees in peak fall foliage.
images.title: Katahdin in autumn
images.caption: Driving the Katahdin Loop Road in the fall offers views of Katahdin framed by vivid foliage.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText: The mile 8 viewpoint on Katahdin Loop Road provides a view of Katahdin framed by forest. The view is especially dramatic during peak fall foliage, which typically occurs in mid to late September.
audioDescription: The dark gray/blue of Mount Katahdin's granite slopes contrasts sharply with a frame of deciduous trees in the vivid reds and yellows of peak fall foliage during September.

quickFacts.value: Mile 8 along the Katahdin Loop Road
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile 8.2 Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint
listingDescription: Discover a spectacular view of both Katahdin and the valley below.

images.altText: Viewpoint seeing Katahdin and surrounding forests. Two skinny spruce stand tall in front.
images.title: Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint - Mile 8.2
images.caption: From this view you can grasp the true scale of the enormity of the Katahdin landscape.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText: At mile 8.2 on the Katahdin Loop Road you can see the glacially carved landscape surrounding Mount Katahdin.
audioDescription: Along a rugged dirt logging road. Looking out to the left Katahdin and a massive forested valley landscape. The forest is a mix between boreal and deciduous forests with species of spruce, pine, hemlock, maple, oak, birch, aspen, and more.

title: Monument Line
listingDescription: Interested in surveys, maps, and history? This historic survey line and marker might be of interest to you!

images.altText: Two signs in the woods, one posted shows the monument line, another indicates the town lines
images.title: A sign indicating an old boundary line
images.caption: These signs show the history of the state of Maine's foundation

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
The Monument Line practically cuts Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument in half. Don't let the name fool you, this survey line is much older than the national monument. 

At the end of the Revolutionary War, the Treaty of Paris failed to specify a clear boundary between Maine and New Brunswick. In 1796, negotiators ran a "monument line" due north from the St. Croix River's headwaters to what was described in the treaty as the "highlands" separating rivers draining into the St. Lawrence from those entering the Atlantic - the agreed-upon northern boundary.

Upon Maine's 1820 separation from Massachusetts, Joseph Norris was hired to lay out the boundaries of these unallocated lands between the two states by blazing the trees with markers. In 1825 Maine formed the Maine Boundary Commission authorizing a survey to establish an east to west line for laying out townships: The Monument Line.

This survey allowed an equitable distribution of lands not already incorporated or otherwise conveyed by Massachusetts. Starting from a point where the boundary between Maine and New Brunswick ceases to be the St. Croix River and heads due north (the 1796 boundary), Joseph C. Norris, Sr., and his son ran the line to the west in the summer of 1825. By September, they had reached the Seboeis River, at which point they had to leave the woods for other survey work. Returning in November Norris built a raft to cross the Seboeis, and continued the line west in the face of approaching winter, crossing the East Branch, the Wassataquoik, and on to Katahdin, where on November 10th, in "intensely cold" weather, he reached an enormous drop-off into Northwest Basin, which forced him to abandon the survey for the year. This line allowed for the formation of townships bringing in people like William Hunt, of the notable Hunt Farm, into the area for logging.

Tensions were already running high as lumber operators from Maine and New Brunswick competed for timber in northern Maine. This would eventually lead to the Aroostook War in 1838.
audioDescription: A flat, grassy dirt road cuts through the boreal forest. On the left side in the woods there is a brown sign marking a boundary. The sign reads "Monument Line, J. Morris Surveyor, November 3 1825." Deeper in the woods, posted on a tree, a white sign with black lettering reads "Town Line T3R8 T4R8."

title: Mount Katahdin - Baxter State Park
listingDescription: Nothing compares to the wildness, beauty, and difficulty of "The Greatest Mountain" in Maine.

images.altText: Pond with rising granite mountain above treeline in the background.
images.title: Katahdin - Baxter State Park
images.caption: Katahdin from Chimney Pond

relatedParks.fullName: Appalachian National Scenic Trail
relatedParks.name: Appalachian

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText:
Katahdin, which translates to "Greatest Mountain" in Penobscot, is the highest mountain in the state of Maine at 5,269 feet.

Katahdin is adjacent to Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument and the prominent visual feature in the region. Katahdin is held sacred by the Maliseet, Micmac, Passamaquoddy, and Penobscot nations and the geology within and around the monument is central to oral histories, traditions, and cultural practices for each tribal community.

Baxter Peak on Mount Katahdin is the northern terminus of the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. For more information about climbing Katahdin visit Baxter State Park's website.
audioDescription: Standing on giant granite boulders covered in a thin layer of lichen. With the iconic Appalachian Trail large wooden brown sign with engraved white lettering. From this elevation, just on the skirts of the clouds you can overlook forests for hundreds of miles in all directions. Immeasurable forests, countless lakes and mountains. If there at the right time the lakes look like that of a broken mirror with thousands of fragments reflecting the sunlight.

quickFacts.value: Northern terminus of Appalachian National Scenic Trail
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: North Gate
listingDescription: The northern access point to the monument offers a parking area, vault toilet, and an information kiosk. This is the trailhead for cross-country ski trails and snowshoeing routes during the winter months (grooming starts early January).

images.altText: Brown wooden sign reads Entering Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument. Map kiosk.
images.title: North Entrance Gate
images.caption: The first stop at the northern entrance to Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText:
The North Gate is the northern access point to the monument. It offers a parking area, vault toilet, and an information kiosk.

During the winter, the parking lot by the North Gate is the only maintained parking area in the monument. Park here and access the trailhead for groomed cross-country ski trails and snowshoeing routes during the winter season. Grooming for cross country ski trails will occur when snow accumulation is adequate.
audioDescription: The northern access point to the monument offers a parking area, vault toilet, and an information kiosk. During the winter, this is only maintained parking area in the monument. Park here and access the trailhead for cross-country ski trails and snowshoeing routes during the winter months. Grooming for cross country ski trails starts when snow accumulation is adequate.

title: Orin Falls
listingDescription: Orin Falls boasts stunning views of a boulder-studded stream with white-water rapids

images.altText: White water rushes between large boulders to form short waterfalls in the stream
images.title: Orin Falls in the Wissataquoik Stream
images.caption: Large boulders help to form the rapids of Orin Falls

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Large boulders in Wassataquoik Stream cause its waters to churn and tumble through the rapids of Orin Falls. The geology in this area hint at a glacial past. This location provides for a scenic picnic and fishing spot. Orin Falls is accessed via a 3 mile out and back hike or bike, mostly along an old streamside logging road. Prepare for high concentrations of biting and stinging insects during the spring and summer months.
 

Elevation Gain: 87ft / 26m

Distance (Round-Trip): 6 Miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: There is a vault toilet located at Wassataquoik Gate parking area

Water: Potable water is not available anywhere inside of Katahdin Woods and Waters. Prepare accordingly.

Parking: Parking is available at Wassataquoik Gate.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife
audioDescription: A walk through the forest opens up to a wide stream filled with large boulders. Large rocks and rapids form white water as the stream creates small waterfalls through the obstructions. Dense forest lines either side of the waterway.

title: Oxbow Picnic Area
listingDescription: A shaded picnic area located atop a steep river embankment

images.altText: A shaded spot on a river embankment overlooks a meandering river
images.title: Oxbow Picnic Area
images.caption: Take a break in the shade and listen to the river meander by.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText:
Oxbow Picnic Area is located at the top of a steep embankment along the East Branch of the Penobscot River. Enjoy a picnic with a view of the waterway as it enters a series of sharp bends known as the Oxbow. 

To get to the Oxbow Picnic Site, follow New River Road south past the North Gate parking area and turn onto Oxbow Road. Follow Oxbow road until you reach the picnic site. There is a vault toilet and a couple picnic tables at this location.
audioDescription: A picnic table sits on a shaded embankment overlooking the East Branch of the Penobscot River below.

title: Park Sign - American Thread Road
listingDescription: One of multiple park signs welcoming you into Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument.

images.altText: A park entrance sign along a dirt logging road with thick forests on both sides of the road.
images.title: Katahdin Woods & Waters Nat. Mon. Sign
images.caption: Park Sign along the American Thread Road welcoming visitors to the Seboeis Parcels.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: The Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument park sign for welcoming visitors into the Seboeis Parcel of the national monument.
audioDescription: A park sign that reads "Entering Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument" is posted along a gravel logging road that is surrounded by deciduous forests.

title: Park Sign - Swift Brook Road
listingDescription: Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument Park Sign that welcomes visitors to the Hunt Farm Parcel of the national monument.

images.altText: Park Sign along a logging road surrounded by deciduous forest.
images.title: Katahdin Woods & Waters Nat. Mon. Sign
images.caption: Park Sign along Swift Brook Road that welcomes visitors to the Hunt Farm Parcel.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument park sign that welcomes visitors to the Hunt Farm parcel of the national monument as they continue to either the Katahdin Loop Road or Lunksoos Camps.
audioDescription: A brown sign with white lettering reads "Entering Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument." It is posted to the side of a gravel road and surrounded by ferns and trees.

title: Pond Pitch
listingDescription: The majestic Pond Pitch is a scenic viewpoint along the East Branch of the Penobscot River and the International Appalachian Trail.

images.altText: A fast-flowing river drops down a small waterfall with rocks and trees on either side.
images.title: Pond Pitch in the Penobscot River
images.caption: Pond Pitch is one of the many rapids in this section of the East Branch Penobscot River

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Pond Pitch is located in the East Branch of the Penobscot River. It gained its name from the pool just above the ledge of the waterfall. It is part of a series of pitches, or rapids, known as Grand Falls. Hike or bike 3 miles out and back to the viewpoint of Pond Pitch. Paddlers are advised to portage around all falls and pitches. Please be mindful of the campsite nearby.
 

Elevation Gain: 140ft / 42m

Distance (Round-Trip): 6 miles

Difficulty: Easy to Moderate

Restrooms: Vault toilets are available at North Gate parking lot and Oxbow Picnic Area. Otherwise, follow best practices for remote waste management.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate trailhead parking.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: A wide, short-dropped waterfall along a white-water rapid in the East Branch of the Penobscot River. There are rocky outcrops and dense green forest on both sides of the river.

title: Rocky Pond Road Trailhead - Katahdin Loop Road - Mile 5.75
listingDescription: Many recreational opportunities await along the Rocky Pond Road Trail.

images.altText: Old rugged dirt logging road going through a forest with two wooden trailhead signs in front.
images.title: Rocky Pond Road Trailhead
images.caption: Many recreation opportunities await along the Rocky Pond Road Trail.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText: The Rocky Pond Road Trail is a 4.1 mile stretch of dirt logging road that allows cycling, hiking, and even horseback riding. Use road with caution. This road is used by authorized vehicles only.
audioDescription: A rugged dirt logging road with deciduous forest all around and two wooden trailhead signs.

title: Rocky Pond Road Trailhead - Katahdin Loop Road - Mile 9
listingDescription: Whether on a horse, a bike, or simply just hiking Rocky Pond Road is a gateway to the forests of Maine.

images.altText: Rugged dirt logging road with wooden trailhead sigh blocking vehicles. Road surrounded by forest.
images.title: Rocky Pond Road Trailhead
images.caption: Rocky Pond Road Trailhead along mile 9 of the Katahdin Loop Road.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: The 4.1 mile Rocky Pond Road Trail allows bicycles, horses, and hikers. This road is used by authorized vehicles only. Use Rocky Pond Road with caution.
audioDescription: A rugged dirt logging road with wooden trailhead signs blocking vehicle access. The road is surrounded by deciduous forests and there is room for parking along the side of the road.

title: Sandbank Gate
listingDescription: Sandbank Gate may be closed in spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy. Travel during this time can cause damage to the road and vehicles

images.altText: A large metal gate closed and locked across a gravel road in the woods.
images.title: Sandbank Gate
images.caption: Sandbank Gate may be closed depending on current conditions.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: Sandbank Stream Gate may be closed in spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy. Travel during this time can cause damage to the road and vehicles.
audioDescription: A metal gate closed across a gravel road in the woods.

title: Seboeis Riverside Trail North Trailhead
listingDescription: A great place to start your journey along the Seboeis River and into Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument by either hiking or paddling.

images.altText: Sign reading "Seboeis Riverside Trail" across the street from a trailhead
images.title: Seboeis Rivertrail N. Terminus Trailhead
images.caption: A great place to start a journey along the wild Seboeis River.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
The northern access point for the Seboeis Riverside Trail is the start of a 6.75 mile one-way trail that leads south along the Seboeis River into the Seboeis Parcel of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.

Across Grand Lake Road is a recreation area where you can access a vault toilet and launch canoes and kayaks to paddle down the Seboeis.
audioDescription: The northern access point for the Seboeis Riverside Trail is the start of a 6.75 mile one-way trail that leads south along the Seboeis River into Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.

title: Seboeis Riverside Trail South Trailhead
listingDescription: A pleasant hike along the banks of the Seboeis River awaits the adventurous!

images.altText: A trailhead is marked by four large boulders stacked on the side of a grassy trail.
images.title: Seboeis Riverside Trail South Trailhead
images.caption: The south end of the Seboeis Riverside Trail is marked by stacked boulders on the side of a trail.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
The southern access point for the Seboeis Riverside Trail is located in the Seboeis Parcel of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument. This trailhead offers a 7.2 mile (one-way) out and back trail along the Seboeis River. The trail extends past the monument boundaries. To get to this location, a high clearance vehicle is recommended. There is an unmarked dirt parking area located just north of the trailhead (46.07529,-68.63553).

Note: Philpott Bridge and areas west of the Seboeis River are not within the boundaries of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.

The northern end of the trail is located off Grand Lake Road, 5.7 miles north of Shin Pond. In the winter, you can snowshoe from the north trailhead. This trailhead is not maintained during the winter.
audioDescription: The south end of the Seboeis Riverside Trail is located in the rugged landscape of the Seboeis Parcel. The start of the trail is marked by several large boulders.

title: Seboeis Road Gate
listingDescription: Gate at entrance to Seboeis Road.

images.altText: Yellow metal gate to the left at the intersection of Swift Brook Road and Seboeis Road.
images.title: Seboeis Road Gate
images.caption: The Seboeis Road Gate is located at the intersection of Swift Brook Road and Seboeis Road.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: The Seboeis Road Gate may be closed in spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy. Travel during this time can cause damage to the road and vehicles. Check current conditions for most up to date information.
audioDescription: Large metal gate across a gravel road at the intersection of Swift Brook Road and Seboeis Road.

title: Slash Trailhead
listingDescription: A great access point at the halfway mark of the Rocky Pond Road Trail.

images.altText: A wooden sign in front of a trail with thick vegetation growing on both sides and Katahdin behind.
images.title: Slash Trailhead
images.caption: Slash Trailhead with Katahdin rising above the trees.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

bodyText:
Slash Trail starts nearby the Katahdin Overlook just off Katahdin Loop Road and connects approximately at the midpoint of Rocky Pond Road Trail. Expect tall grasses and thick vegetation along the trail.
 

Elevation Gain: 201ft / 61.3m

Distance(Round-Trip): 1.2 miles/ 1.9km

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: The closest vault toilet is at the Katahdin Loop Road Overlook.

Parking: Park completely off the gravel road. Do not block the road or trailhead.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: Wooden Trailhead sign with thick vegetation and trees growing on either side of the trail. Katahdin rises above the tress in the background. The loop road passes by behind.

title: Stair Falls
listingDescription: Stair Falls is a rapid that resembles a staircase waterfall in the East Branch of the Penobscot River.

images.altText: Water flows over rock ledges resembling stairs in the East Branch Penobscot River..
images.title: Stair Falls
images.caption: Stair Falls is named for its step-like rapid formations

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
The East Branch of the Penobscot River flows over a series of parallel bedrock ridges that cause the river to appear to be flowing over stairs as it drops 18 feet within 8/10 of a mile. The name came from Maynard Marsh through a survey commissioned by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in 1793. In his field notes Marsh wrote, "...at the foot of the handsomest falls I ever saw... as regular as a stair case." Stair Falls was recognized as a significant rapid in the state of Maine's evaluations of critical areas in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Access to the falls is along the International Appalachian Trail, with the fastest route beginning at Haskell Gate. Please be mindful that there is a campsite in this area.
 

Elevation Gain: 87ft / 26m

Distance (Round-Trip): 4 miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: The closest vault toilets are located at the North Gate parking lot and the Oxbow Picnic Area.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate trailhead on New River Road.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife. Be mindful of the campsite area when visiting the falls.
audioDescription: A series of white-water rapids along a wide river. The way that the water progressively drops over the span of river gives the rapids the appearance of a staircase. The water runs from north to south. Trees line both sides of the river. A small mountain top peaks above the tree line upstream.

title: Swift Brook Road Gate
listingDescription: The Swift Brook Road Gate may be closed in spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy. Travel during this time can cause damage to the road and vehicles.

images.altText: A large orange metal gate is locked closed across a gravel road in the woods.
images.title: Swift Brook Road Gate (orange)
images.caption: Swift Brook Gate is closed seasonally depending on current conditions.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: The Swift Brook Road Gate may be closed in spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy. This gate is not managed by NPS. Travel during this time can cause damage to the road and vehicles.
audioDescription: An orange gate closed across gravel road in the woods.

title: The Hulling Machine
listingDescription: The breathtaking views of this waterfall can only be glimpsed by experienced, adventurous paddlers.

images.altText: A large waterfall with granite cliff banks along the shores with forests above.
images.title: The Hulling Machine
images.caption: Portage around The Hulling Machine in the East Branch of the Penobscot River.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: The Hulling Machine is a beautiful waterfall that can only be seen and heard by paddling down the East Branch of the Penobscot River. You must portage around The Hulling Machine. This natural feature was named for what it did to logs as they passed through the rapids and ledge drops. Logs were once floated downstream by loggers to transport them by river during the log driving days.
audioDescription: A white-water river rapid with rushing waterfalls flowing over large brown and gray rocks. Thick forests grow along the rocky banks of the river.

title: Twin Ponds
listingDescription: Twin Ponds is a wetland area located off the American Thread Road. Hike to this location for a chance to observe waterfowl and other aquatic wildlife.

images.altText: A still pond reflects trees with autumn colors and pines
images.title: Twin ponds view
images.caption: Twin Ponds provides a serene pond view after a short hike.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Twin Ponds is a wetland area located just off the American Thread Road. Take a short hike to the viewpoint where there may be a chance to observe waterfowl and other wildlife.

Elevation Gain: none

Distance (Round-Trip): 0.5 miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: There are no restrooms available in this section of the monument.

Parking: Parking is available at the trailhead located on the American Thread Road.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: A large open wetland area surrounded by grassy shores and dense forest.

title: Valley Viewpoint
listingDescription: Valley View offers a remote experience at an incredible view of the treasured landscape of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.

images.altText: A large flat rockface surrounded by pine trees. Rolling mountains fade into the horizon.
images.title: The vista from Valley Viewpoint
images.caption: The stunning vista from Valley Viewpoint shows the monument's eastern landscape.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Valley Viewpoint offers a vista that focuses on the landscape of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument and surrounding areas. To enjoy this scenic view, hike or bike 8 miles (one way) from Haskell Gate. This trail is considered strenuous with 1,369ft of elevation gain. Keep in mind, this is a 16 mile hike round trip. Due to its remote location, it is one of the least visited views in the monument. Hike or Bike to Valley View from Haskell Gate along the International Appalachian Trail.

Be prepared by bringing a map, food, and plenty of water. Check current conditions and local weather before visiting.

If you plan to visit this location in the winter, you will start your adventure by skiing or snowshoeing from the North Gate parking lot. Starting at North Gate parking lot increases the mileage to 22 miles (round-trip). Know your limits before your visit and review information on winter safety. Remember to pack your own snowshoes and/or skis!
 

Elevation Gain: 1,369ft / 417m

Distance(Round-Trip): 16 miles

Difficulty: Difficult

Restrooms: Vault toilets are available at the North Gate parking lot and Oxbow Picnic Area.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate trailhead parking area.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.
audioDescription: An open expanse of subalpine landscape and granite slabs offer a view of the breathtaking glacially carved landscape within the national monument. The lookout hosts a wide-angle view of a wild stream, rolling green mountains, and breathtaking deciduous and boreal forests.

title: Wassataquoik Gate Parking Lot
listingDescription: The Wassataquoik Gate is the trailhead to many of the national monument's backcountry trails.

images.altText: Signs in middle of road with bathroom in the distance. Forests surround the road.
images.title: Wassataquoik Gate
images.caption: Wassataquoik Gate is the trailhead for many destinations within the national monument.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
Wassataquoik Gate Parking Lot is the trailhead for destinations like Orin Falls (2.9 miles one-way), Deasey Mountain (5 miles one-way), and several campsites reachable by foot. The hike to Deasey Mountain requires a crossing of Wassataquoik Stream. Barnard Mountain (4.1 miles one-way) can also be reached from this parking lot. 

Accessibility:
The surface of the parking area is made of dirt, gravel, and rocks. It is leveled, but the surface can be uneven and muddy depending on the season. The vault toilet meets ADA standards.

Hours:
Open 24/7 when the Katahdin Loop Road is opened to traffic.

Getting Here:
Take Swift Brook Road past the welcome sign at the Loop Road Gate. Continue for approximately 1.9 miles to meet a junction. Turn right on the Loop Road towards Wassataquoik Stream Road. Continue for approximately 1.3 miles and turn right onto Wassataquoik Stream Road. Once on Wassataquoik Stream Road, travel for approximately 2.5 miles to reach the parking lot.
audioDescription: Dirt and gravel surfaced parking lot with a vault toilet. Signs block vehicle traffic from going any further past the trailhead. The parking lot is surrounded by forest.

title: Wassataquoik Stream Ford
listingDescription: The Wassataquoik Stream Ford feels like a natural boundary between civilization and the wild backcountry to the north.

images.altText: A backpacker in thigh deep water crosses a stream to the opposite shore.
images.title: Crossing Wassataquoik Stream at the Ford
images.caption: Crossing at the Wassataquoik Ford is necessary to follow the International Appalachian Trail.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText:
The Wassataquoik Ford is the designated crossing point for the IAT across Wassataquoik Stream. Look for the signs marked "FORD" on either side of the river for the crossing points. Proceed with caution. Wassataquoik Stream is prone to flash floods. Review information about stream crossing safety. Do not cross if water levels are high or if you do not feel comfortable with the conditions. 

Always be willing to turn back or wait for a more suitable time if a crossing appears too dangerous! Remember, no river crossing is worth your life.
audioDescription: Wassataquoik Stream is a wide stream clear enough to see the rocky bottom. The stream flows can vary greatly at this location depending on conditions. Thick vegetation grows on the shores, and forest surrounds both sides of the water. The banks are rocky, uneven, and steep.

title: Wassataquoik Stream Road Gate
listingDescription: The Orin Falls Road leads to several hiking and biking opportunities such as access to the IAT and Orin Falls. The gate may be closed in spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy.

images.altText: A rugged dirt logging road with an open gate surrounded by forest.
images.title: Wassataquoik Stream Road Gate
images.caption: Wassataquoik Stream Road is typically open to vehicles. The gate may be closed during mud season.

relatedParks.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
relatedParks.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

tags: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
bodyText: The Wassataquoik Stream Road Gate is usually open, but may be closed in the spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy. Travel during this time can cause damage to the road and vehicles.
audioDescription: A rugged dirt logging road with an old metal gate that is open. The road is surrounded by thick young deciduous forest.
